description: Preposition and verb from Middle English in, from Old English in, from Proto-Germanic *in.
Adverb, noun and adjective from Middle English in, from Old English inn and inne, from Proto-Germanic *innai.

adjectives.description: in (comparative more in, superlative most in)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Located indoors, especially at home or at one's office or place of work.
examples: Is Mr. Smith in?

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Located inside something.
examples: Little by little I pushed the snake into the basket, until finally all of it was in.

entries.meaning: (sports, of the ball or other playing implement) Falling or remaining within the bounds of the playing area.
examples: If the tennis ball bounces on the line then it's in.

entries.meaning: Inserted or fitted into something.
examples: I've discovered why the TV wasn't working – the plug wasn't in!

entries.meaning: Having been collected or received.
examples: The replies to the questionnaires are now all in.

entries.meaning: In fashion; popular.
examples: Skirts are in this year.

entries.meaning: Incoming.
examples: the in train

entries.meaning: (nautical, of the sails of a vessel) Furled or stowed.
Of the tide, at or near its highest level.
examples: You can't get round the headland when the tide's in.

entries.meaning: (law) With privilege or possession; used to denote a holding, possession, or seisin
examples: in by descent; in by purchase; in of the seisin of her husband

entries.meaning: (cricket) Currently batting.
Having familiarity or involvement with somebody.
examples: He is very in with the Joneses.

entries.meaning: (informal) Having a favourable position, such as a position of influence or expected gain, in relation to another person.
examples: I think that bird fancies you. You're in there, mate!

entries.meaning: (of fire or fuel) (Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand) Burning; ablaze.
At or towards the interior of a defined space, such as a building or room.
examples: Suddenly a strange man walked in.
Would you like that to take away or eat in?
He ran to the edge of the swimming pool and dived in.

entries.meaning: Towards the speaker or other reference point.
examples: They flew in from London last night.
For six hours the tide flows in, then for another six hours it flows out.

entries.meaning: So as to be enclosed or surrounded by something.
examples: Bring the water to the boil and drop the vegetables in.

entries.meaning: After the beginning of something.
examples: The show still didn't become interesting 20 minutes in.

entries.meaning: (in combination, after a verb) Denotes a gathering of people assembled for the stated activity, sometimes, though not always, suggesting a protest.
examples: sing-in, pray-in, hug-in; see also be-in, love-in, sit-in, teach-in.

entries.meaning: A position of power or influence, or a way to get it.
examples: His parents got him an in with the company.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) One who, or that which, is in; especially, one who is in office.
examples: Antonym: out

entries.meaning: (sports) The state of a batter/batsman who is currently batting; see innings.
A re-entrant angle; a nook or corner.

definitionGroups.group: Used to indicate location, inclusion, or position within spatial, temporal or other limits.

entries.meaning: Contained by.
examples: The dog is in the kennel.
There were three pickles in a jar.

entries.meaning: Within the bounds or limits of.
examples: I like living in the city.
There are lots of trees in the park.

entries.meaning: Surrounded by; among; amidst.
examples: We are in the enemy camp.
Her plane is in the air.
Waiter! There's a fly in my soup!

entries.meaning: Wearing (an item of clothing).
examples: I glanced over at the pretty girl in the red dress.

entries.meaning: Part of; a member of; out of; from among.
examples: You are one in a million.
She's in an orchestra.

entries.meaning: During (a period of time).
examples: My birthday is in the first week of December.
Easter falls in the fourth lunar month.
The country reached a high level of prosperity in his first term.

entries.meaning: Within (a certain elapsed time); by the end of.
examples: Will you be able to finish this in a week?
The massacre resulted in over 1000 deaths in three hours.

entries.meaning: At the end of (a period of time).
examples: They said they would call us in a week.

entries.meaning: (grammar, phonetics) Characterized by.
examples: Many English nouns in -is form their plurals in -es.

entries.meaning: Into.
examples: Less water gets in your boots this way.
She stood there looking in the window longingly.

definitionGroups.group: Used to indicate limit, qualification, condition, or circumstance.

entries.meaning: Indicating an order or arrangement.
examples: My fat rolls around in folds.

entries.meaning: Denoting a state of the subject.
examples: He stalked away in anger.
John is in a coma.

entries.meaning: Indicates, connotatively, a place-like form of someone's (or something's) personality, as his, her or its psychic and physical characteristics.
examples: You've got a friend in me.
He's met his match in her.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to; with regard to.
examples: There has been no change in his condition.
What grade did he get in English?

definitionGroups.group: Used to indicate means, medium, format, genre, or instrumentality.

entries.meaning: (of something offered or given in an exchange) In the form of, in the denomination of.
examples: Please pay me in cash — preferably in tens and twenties.
The deposit can be in any legal tender, even in gold.
Her generosity was rewarded in the success of its recipients.

entries.meaning: Used to indicate a language, script, tone, etc. of a text, speech, etc.
examples: Beethoven's "Symphony No. 5" in C minor is among his most popular.
His speech was in French, but was simultaneously translated into eight languages.
When you write in cursive, it's illegible.
Military letters should be formal in tone, but not stilted.

verbs.description: in (third-person singular simple present ins, present participle inning, simple past and past participle inned)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To enclose.
(obsolete, transitive) To take in; to harvest.
Abbreviation of inch; inches.
